Outline and Discussion of the Rubber Hand Illusion (RHI)

1. Original Experiment

The Rubber Hand Illusion (RHI) demonstrates how multisensory integration can alter body ownership. In the classic setup, a participant's real hand is hidden from view while a rubber hand is placed in front of them. Both the real and rubber hands are stroked synchronously with a brush. Participants often report feeling the touch on the rubber hand and perceive it as part of their body. This illusion is driven by the brain's integration of visual, tactile, and proprioceptive inputs ; .

2. Replications and Variations

  • Virtual Reality (VR): Studies have replicated the RHI using VR, where participants experience ownership over virtual hands. VR conditions often enhance the illusion compared to physical setups ; .
  • Temporal Delays: Research shows that synchronous stimulation must occur within 300 ms for the illusion to be effective, highlighting the importance of timing in multisensory integration .
  • Supernumerary Limbs: Variations have induced ownership of additional limbs, such as a "third hand," challenging the traditional body schema .
  • Affective Touch: Slow, pleasant stroking enhances the illusion, suggesting interoceptive signals contribute to body ownership .

3. Applications and Significance

The RHI has implications for prosthetics, virtual reality, and rehabilitation. It provides insights into how the brain constructs body ownership, which can inform the design of more intuitive prosthetic devices and immersive VR systems ; .
